title: Most Extinction Rebellion activists did not want to disrupt the Tube
text:
The majority of XR activists are opposed to disrupting the Tube

Extinction Rebellion activists have apologised for the disruption caused when a handful of supporters brought parts of the tube network to a standstill.

The vast majority of environment campaigners are said to be against such action but an affinity group went ahead anyway.

On Thursday morning, commuters fought back against the rebel protesters who had scaled a train at Canning Town station.

They held a sign which read ‘Business as usual = death’ but were met with fury by angry people trying to get to work.

Two activists used a ladder to climb up onto the carriage, causing passengers to shout at them before launching a physical attack.

Eight people were arrested by British Transport Police after there were also incidents at Shadwell and Stratford stations.

Protesters scaled a train at Canning Town underground station (Picture: Extinction Rebellion)

Commuters were angry at not being able to get to work

However many within the group felt that targeting public transport and stopping people getting to work sent a counter-productive message.

Advertisement

XR South West Britain said: ‘The action this morning was hugely unpopular within XR. Many of us wrote to the actions group to ask that the event be stopped.

‘A poll was run with a significant majority voting against it.

‘Many of us felt it was wrong to target the Tube and disrupt people using a form of transport that is part of the solution in a zero-carbon world.

‘Secondly, many of us felt that targeting stations in poorer parts of London, that are home to people economically on the edge, was deeply problematic.

‘It gave strength to the damaging narrative that XR is largely white, privileged and middle class, with little understanding of issues that, at root, are closely related to the immediate issues that we are attempting to meet.’

Other activists said it distracted from other protests outside an arms fair.

XR reportedly carried out an internal poll to question members how they felt about action on the London underground – which handles around five million journeys per day.

Some 72% were completely opposed while a further 14% did not want it to happen if people might be blocked underground.

Around 7% of those who replied to the poll said they approved of action against the tube network if trains would not get blocked underground.

Just 4% approved of causing chaos on the transport network saying it was ‘up to the affinity groups to decide how to do it.’

Extinction Rebellion protesters glued themselves to trains (Picture: Twitter)

The activists caused chaos to Londoners trying to use public transport to get to work (Picture: Twitter)

Commuters pleaded to be allowed to get to work, pointing out they had families to feed.

Advertisement

Advertisement

XR spokesperson Robin Boardman, 21, said the move was not designed to ‘inconvenience ordinary people’ but it was the only way to get the government to ‘take notice’.

He continued: ‘That’s why we’re doing this in the morning when it will impact business as usual, and not in the evening, when people want to get home to be with their loved ones.’

The action was intended to only disrupt Tube lines leading into the ‘richest part of London’, and cause a negative impact on business as a result, a statement from XR said.

An activist is dragged off the train

They targeted Stratford, Shadwell and Canning Town station (Picture: Vladimir Morozov/ akxmedia @lepkirk)

The action is the latest in a series from the anti-climate change group, who have been banned from protesting in London.

Any assembly of more than two people linked to the XR Autumn Uprising action is now illegal in the capital.

Since last week, protesters have targeted London City Airport, shut down areas around Parliament and the Bank of England, and blockaded Google’s HQ, with more than 1,600 people arrested.
